title: Jessica Williams and Salma Hayek had a tense conversation about race at Sundance
text:
A conversation at the Sundance Film Festival meant to bring together women in film got a little heated last week, when Jessica Williams and Salma Hayek got into a debate regarding race and intersectional feminism.
The LA Times reported on the on-the-record luncheon co-sponsored by Glamour magazine and Girlgaze and people are unhappy with Hayek's and other actresses' remarks.
SEE ALSO: Top 10 Movies from Sundance 2017
The luncheon was meant as a forum for women in film to discuss, network and celebrate accomplishments ‚Äî however, according to the Times , things took a turn for the uncomfortable as the topic shifted to the political climate.
Hayek warned those gathered to not "fall into victimization" because of their gender.
"I don‚Äôt want to be hired because I‚Äôm a girl. I want them to see I‚Äôm fabulous. Don‚Äôt give me a job because I‚Äôm a girl. It‚Äôs condescending," Hayek reportedly said, before Shirley MacLaine chimed in and challenged others to uncover their "core identity."
Williams challenged these with her own perspective. ‚ÄúMy question is: What if you are a person of color, or a transgendered [sic] person who ‚Äî just from how you look ‚Äî you already are in a conflict?," she asked. MacLaine then reportedly told her to "change her point of view of being victimized."
The tense exchange went on, with Hayek encouraging Williams to try to identify as someone other than a black woman.
‚ÄúWho are you when you‚Äôre not black and you‚Äôre not a woman?" Hayek said. "Who are you and what have you got to give?‚Äù
"A lot. But some days, I‚Äôm just black, and I‚Äôm just a woman,‚Äù Williams responded. ‚ÄúLike, it‚Äôs not my choice. I know who I am. I know I‚Äôm Jessica, and I‚Äôm the hottest bitch on the planet I know."
In response, Hayek (who was born in Mexico) asked Williams to accept identity as a choice.
As Times reporter Amy Quote: :
Williams, visibly uncomfortable, said she also wanted to encourage all of the women in the room to pay special attention to women of color and LGBT women. ‚ÄúI think we need to not speak over black women,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúnot assign them labels.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat does this mean, ‚Äòspeak over?‚Äô‚Äù Hayek asked.
‚ÄúTo project your ideas on me,‚Äù Williams said. ‚ÄúI think there is a fear that if we present an idea that, ‚ÄòHey, maybe [black women] have it a little bit harder in this country‚Äô ‚Äî because we do; black women and trans women do ‚Äî if we‚Äôre having it a little bit harder, it doesn‚Äôt invalidate your experience. I really am begging you to not take it personally.‚Äù
The conversation continued with others chiming in to support Williams' point that different women deal with the weight of a wide range of experiences ‚Äî and the importance of acknowledging the burdens and experiences of black women through an intersectional framework, not victimization.
The full text, which you can read here , sparked a dialogue on Twitter, particularly from black women who tweeted in support of Williams.
